<Summary source="https://www.macrumors.com/2026/01/29/apple-1q-2026-earnings/">
# Summary of Apple Q1 2026 Financial Results Article

**Source:** MacRumors, January 29, 2026, by Jordan Golson

## Key Financial Facts and Statistics:

**Q1 2026 Results (Oct-Dec 2025 calendar quarter):**
- Total revenue: $143.8 billion (up 16% year-over-year from $124.3 billion)
- Net profit: $42.1 billion (up from $36.3 billion year-ago)
- Earnings per share: $2.84 per diluted share (up 19% from $2.40 year-ago)
- Gross margin: 48.2% (compared to 46.9% year-ago)
- Operating cash flow: $53.9 billion (all-time record)
- Quarterly dividend: $0.26 per share, payable February 12

**Revenue by Product Category:**
- iPhone: $85.3 billion (up 23.3% year-over-year) - all-time record
- Services: $30 billion (up 13.9%) - all-time record
- iPad: $8.6 billion (up 6.3%)
- Mac: $8.4 billion (down 6.7%)
- Wearables, Home and Accessories: $11.5 billion (down 2.2%)

**Revenue by Geographic Segment:**
- Greater China: up 37.9%
- Europe: up 12.7%
- Americas: up 11.2%
- Rest of Asia Pacific: up 18.0%
- Japan: up 4.7%

**Other Metrics:**
- Active device installed base: over 2.5 billion devices
- Products gross margin: 40.7%
- Services gross margin: 76.5%
- Operating expenses: $18.4 billion (up 19% year-over-year)

**Q2 2026 Guidance (current quarter ending March):**
- Projected year-over-year revenue growth: 13% to 16%
- Projected gross margin: 48% to 49%

## Named Source Opinions:

**Tim Cook (Apple CEO):**
- Called it "a remarkable, record-breaking quarter"
- Described iPhone demand as "simply staggering"
- Stated "This is the strongest iPhone lineup we've ever had and by far the most popular"

**Kevan Parekh (Apple CFO):**
- Noted "exceptionally strong results generated nearly $54 billion in operating cash flow, allowing us to return almost $32 billion to shareholders"

## Additional Information:
- Stock price was up almost 2% in after-hours trading following the earnings release (as of article publication)
- Customer satisfaction for iPhone 17 family measured at 99% by 451 Research
- Mac customer satisfaction measured at 97%
- Apple TV viewership increased 36% in December over prior year
- App Store developers have earned over $550 billion since 2008
- Apple announced collaboration with Google to develop next-generation Apple foundation models for future Apple Intelligence features
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/apple-tops-q1-earnings-estimates-on-record-breaking-iphone-sales-stock-falls-after-cooks-memory-warning-213019588.html">
# Summary of Article: Apple Q1 Earnings Report (January 30, 2026)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Earnings Performance (Q1):**
- Apple beat Wall Street expectations on both revenue and earnings
- Earnings per share (EPS): $2.84 (vs. analyst estimate of $2.68)
- Total revenue: $143.8 billion (vs. analyst estimate of $138.4 billion)

**Revenue Breakdown by Product/Service:**
- iPhone revenue: $85.3 billion (all-time record, vs. analyst estimate of $78.3 billion and $69.1 billion in same quarter last year)
- Services: $30 billion (in line with expectations)
- Mac: $8.4 billion
- iPad: $8.6 billion
- Wearables: $11.5 billion

**Regional Performance:**
- China sales: $25.5 billion, up nearly 38% year-over-year (notable turnaround after sales declined in 3 of the last 4 quarters)

**Margins:**
- Q1 gross margins: 48%
- Q2 projected margins: 48-49%

## Named Source Opinions:

**Tim Cook (Apple CEO):**
- Warned that the global memory crunch will negatively impact the company's margins going forward
- The memory shortage is attributed to AI data center buildout putting massive strain on memory chip market

## Market Reaction:

- Apple stock edged lower early Friday (January 30, 2026), retracing an initial slight gain after the earnings release

## Additional Context:

- Apple is acquiring startup Q.AI for $2 billion (per The Information)
- Apple and Google announced partnership where Apple will use Google's Gemini models and cloud technology for AI efforts, including a more personalized Siri due later in 2026
- Apple's AI development has been lagging behind rivals like Samsung; the company has delayed its fully revamped Siri until later in 2026 due to quality issues
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://investor.apple.com/investor-relations/default.aspx">
# Summary of Article

**Source:** Investor.apple (Investor Relations page)

**Key Facts:**

1. **Event:** Apple will host its 2026 Annual Meeting of Shareholders
2. **Date and Time:** February 24, 2026 at 8:00 am Pacific Time
3. **Format:** Virtual meeting
4. **Access:** Available at www.virtualshareholdermeeting.com/AAPL2026
5. **Record Date:** January 2, 2026
6. **Voting Requirements:** Shareholders will need a unique control number (provided by their bank, broker, or other organization holding their shares) to access and vote during the meeting
7. **Additional Information:** Further details about the meeting and voting matters are available in Apple's proxy statement

**Relevance to Forecast Question:**

This article provides administrative information about Apple's upcoming shareholder meeting but does not contain any facts, statistics, financial data, or expert opinions that would directly inform a forecast about AAPL's stock price movement between February 2 and February 15, 2026.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnn.com/2026/01/01/investing/what-to-expect-stock-market-2026">
# Summary of "What to expect from stocks in 2026" (CNN Business, January 1, 2026)

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **S&P 500 ending position (2025):** 6,845.5 points
- **2025 performance:** S&P 500 gained more than 16% with 39 new record highs; experienced a 19% decline in April due to tariff concerns before rebounding
- **Historical pattern:** When S&P 500 gains at least 15% in a year, the following year's returns have averaged about 8%, with an average decline of roughly 14% at some point before rebounding (per Adam Turnquist, LPL Financial)
- **Gold performance:** Best year since 1979

## Wall Street 2026 Price Targets for S&P 500:

- **Bank of America:** 7,100 (3.72% gain)
- **Deutsche Bank:** 8,000 (16.87% gain)
- **Goldman Sachs (Peter Oppenheimer):** Constructive on equities but forecasts lower returns than 2025
- **Ed Yardeni (Yardeni Research):** 7,700 (12.5% gain); assigns 20% odds to severe correction or bear market
- **Christopher Harvey (CIBC Capital Markets):** Roughly 8.8% gain

**Note:** All reviewed forecasts expect positive gains for 2026.

## Bullish Factors Cited:

- **AI-driven growth:** Described as a "supercycle" fueling record capital expenditures and earnings expansion
- **Expected Fed rate cuts** in 2026
- **Resilient corporate earnings** and continued growth
- **Strong consumer spending** from wealthier households
- **Market breadening:** In November, Dow began outpacing Nasdaq, indicating rally spreading beyond AI stocks
- **Economic conditions:** "Inflation is benign, interest rates are trending lower and earnings are trending higher" (Terry Sandven, US Bank Asset Management)

## Named Analyst Opinions:

- **Dan Ives (Wedbush Securities):** Top 5 stock picks for 2026 include **Apple (AAPL)**, along with Nvidia, Microsoft, Tesla, and Palantir
- **Hardika Singh (Fundstrat):** "This year's gains have shown that the bull market is all gas, no brakes... there are few solid reasons to believe this run can't extend into the next year"
- **JPMorgan Chase analysts:** "The US is set to remain the world's growth engine, driven by a resilient economy and an AI-driven supercycle"

## Risk Factors Identified:

- **High valuations:** US stocks becoming increasingly expensive; high valuations can correspond with undersized future returns
- **Geopolitical tensions:** Ongoing concerns
- **Tariff uncertainty:** Trump's tariff policies created volatility in 2025
- **Fed independence concerns:** Uncertainty about Trump's pick for Fed Chair; questions about central bank independence
- **Stubborn inflation:** Could complicate Fed's rate-cutting path
- **K-shaped economy:** Spending concentrated among wealthy consumers; lower-income consumers struggling
- **Labor market health:** Key for gauging consumer spending sustainability
- **Credit market concerns**
- **AI spending returns:** Potential nerves about return on investment
- **US-Mexico-Canada trade agreement:** Set to expire in 2026
- **Long-term borrowing costs:** Rising globally
- **Government deficits:** Persistently large
- **Fabio Bassi (JPMorgan Chase):** "The market environment remains fragile, and investors must navigate a landscape where risk and resilience coexist"

## Context on 2025 Market Drivers:

Stock gains were supported by tech/AI enthusiasm, trade tension detente, Fed rate cut optimism, and robust corporate earnings, despite challenges from tariff announcements, geopolitical tensions, and concerns about AI bubble.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.fool.com/investing/2026/01/29/buy-apple-dow-jones-stock-sell-off/">
# Summary of Article: "Apple Is the Second-Worst-Performing Dow Jones Stock So Far in 2026. Is the Sell-Off a Buying Opportunity?"

**Source:** The Motley Fool  
**Date:** January 29, 2026  
**Author:** Daniel Foelber

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Stock Performance:**
   - Apple down 8.8% year-to-date (as of January 29, 2026)
   - S&P 500 up 1% in same period
   - Apple is the second-worst-performing Dow Jones Industrial Average component
   - Stock gained 32.5% in second half of 2025
   - Apple added more than $1 trillion in market cap in the months leading into 2026
   - Stock still up significantly over the last seven months despite recent pullback

2. **Financial Performance (Fiscal 2025):**
   - Product revenue grew 4.1%
   - Services revenue jumped 13.5%
   - Products gross margin: 36.8%
   - Services gross margin: 75.4%
   - Services now represent 26.2% of total sales
   - Strong performance in North America and growth in Europe and Asia (excluding China)
   - China sales declined

3. **Valuation Metrics:**
   - Forward P/E ratio: 30.9
   - Analyst estimates: 10.3% earnings growth in fiscal 2026, 10.5% in fiscal 2027
   - More expensive than Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft, and Meta Platforms
   - Broadcom has 31.6 forward P/E
   - Nvidia has forward P/E under 40

4. **Product Pipeline:**
   - iPhone 17 launched September 2025 with improvements in camera, processing, and design
   - iPhone 18 expected with AI-powered software upgrades
   - iPhone 18 may feature first-ever foldable design
   - Higher-end iPhone 18 versions expected to use Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing's 2-nanometer chips
   - Expected to be "by far the most expensive iPhone ever" with drastically improved processing and battery life

## Author's Opinion (Named Source - Daniel Foelber):

- Apple is "a decent stock to buy in 2026, but it's not all that compelling"
- Would choose other major tech stocks (Amazon, Alphabet, Microsoft, Meta, Broadcom, Nvidia) over Apple due to "strong competitive moats and more attractive valuations relative to their growth potential"
- Prefers high-yield dividend stocks like Coca-Cola and Procter & Gamble for consumer-facing investments
- Notes Apple's business model is heavily dependent on consumer spending, making it more sensitive to economic conditions than B2B-focused tech companies
- Acknowledges Apple would likely hold up better than other AI stocks if there's a pullback in hyperscaler spending on AI
- Conclusion: "there are worse ideas than buying Apple after its latest pullback, but it's not a screaming buying opportunity by any means"

## Additional Context:

- Apple sold off in first half of 2025 due to tariff-related fears that "never came true"
- Company is implementing voice-controlled AI assistant gradually
- Apple has "an impeccable balance sheet and consistently generates gobs of free cash flow"
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.barchart.com/story/news/35870941/why-the-next-quarter-could-be-the-best-ever-for-apple-stock">
# Summary of "Why the Next Quarter Could Be the 'Best Ever' for Apple Stock"

**Publication Details:**
- Source: Barchart.com
- Date: November 03, 2025
- Author: Aditya Raghunath

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Revenue Guidance and Forecasts:**
- Apple forecasts Q1 2026 (December quarter) revenue growth of 10-12% year-over-year
- Fiscal Q1 2025 (ended December 2024) reported sales: $124.3 billion
- Midpoint estimate for Q1 2026: $138 billion (above consensus of $132.3 billion)
- Q4 2025 (ended September) revenue: $102.47 billion, up 9% YoY

**Services Performance:**
- Services sales in Q4: $29 billion, up 15% YoY
- Full fiscal year Services revenue: over $100 billion (14% YoY increase)
- Payment services reached all-time revenue record with double-digit growth in Apple Pay active users

**Other Product Categories:**
- Mac sales increased 13% in Q4
- China growth expected to turn positive in Q1 2026 after 4% decline in Q4

**Customer Metrics:**
- Customer satisfaction: 98% for iPhone (US), 96% for Mac, 98% for iPad
- Installed base of active devices reached all-time highs across every product category and geographic segment
- Over 50% of Apple Watch purchasers in the quarter were new to the product

**Stock Valuation (as of article date):**
- Market cap: $4 trillion
- Current stock price: $271
- 12-month return: 20%
- 10-year return: over 900% (adjusted for dividend reinvestments)
- Forward P/E ratio: 32.8x (vs. 10-year average of 22.2x)

**Manufacturing and Investment:**
- $600 billion committed to U.S. investments over four years
- Expected to support over 450,000 jobs
- New Houston facility producing servers for Apple Intelligence

## Named Source Opinions:

**Citi analyst Atif Malik:**
- Characterized this as a record-breaking upgrade cycle
- Noted customers upgrading from all previous iPhone generations
- Emphasized simultaneous increases in upgrade rates and total upgrading customers
- Raised price target from $245 to $315 (16% upside from $271)

**CEO Tim Cook:**
- Attributed bullish outlook to "off-the-chart" demand for iPhone 17 devices
- Cited increased store traffic globally

## Analyst Consensus:
- Out of 41 analysts: 22 "Strong Buy," 2 "Moderate Buy," 15 "Hold," 1 "Moderate Sell," 1 "Strong Sell"
- Average price target: $259.39 (below current price of $271 at time of article)

## Forward-Looking Projections:
- Revenue forecast: $416.16 billion (fiscal 2025) to $577 billion (fiscal 2030)
- Adjusted earnings forecast: $7.46 per share (fiscal 2025) to $13.77 per share (fiscal 2030)

**Note:** This article was published on November 3, 2025, which is prior to the forecast period in question (February 2026).
</Summary>

Query: Will AAPL's market close price on 2026-02-15 be higher than its market close price on 2026-02-02?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Apple Inc. $AAPL is Legacy Trust's Largest Position**
Legacy Trust increased its stake in Apple Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL) by 58.3% in the third quarter, acquiring 45,193 additional shares, bringing its total ownership to 122,764 shares, valued at $31,259,000, making Apple its largest holding at 6.2% of the portfolio. Other institutional investors also adjusted their positions: Capstone Wealth Management LLC increased by 0.5%, Baker Boyer National Bank by 0.3%, Beddow Capital Management Inc. by 1.8%, Uncommon Cents Investing LLC by 0.4%, and Vermillion Wealth Management Inc. by 0.5%, each purchasing 47 additional shares. Institutional ownership of Apple stands at 67.73%, while insiders own 0.06%. Insider Chris Kondo sold 3,752 shares on November 7, 2025, at an average price of $271.23, reducing his ownership by 19.90%. Analysts have issued a mix of ratings: one 'Strong Buy', twenty-two 'Buy', eleven 'Hold', and one 'Sell', resulting in a consensus 'Moderate Buy' rating and a consensus price target of $289.23. Positive sentiment is driven by record revenue and EPS beats, strong iPhone 17 sales, and analyst upgrades (e.g., TD Cowen, JPMorgan). Neutral sentiment surrounds Apple’s ambiguous AI strategy despite partnerships (e.g., Google Gemini) and M&A (Q.ai), while negative sentiment arises from rising memory chip costs, TSMC supply constraints limiting iPhone production, AI researcher departures, and early-stage exploration of U.S. foundry partnerships (e.g., Intel). Apple announced a quarterly dividend of $0.26 per share, payable on February 12, 2026, to shareholders of record on February 9, 2026, yielding 0.4% annually. The company reported $2.84 EPS and $143.76 billion in revenue for Q4 2025, surpassing estimates of $2.67 EPS and $138.25 billion in revenue, with a 15.7% year-over-year revenue increase. Apple’s market cap is $3.81 trillion, PE ratio is 32.80, debt-to-equity is 0.87, and beta is 1.09. The stock’s 52-week range is $169.21 to $288.62.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 02, 2026 10:44 AM
Source:[Defense World](https://www.defenseworld.net/2026/02/02/apple-inc-aapl-is-legacy-trusts-largest-position.html)

**S&P 500 Extends Losses for Third Day, Markets Close January on a High Despite Ongoing Investor Caution**
The S&P 500 index closed lower for the third consecutive day on Friday, February 2, 2026, despite finishing January with a 1.4% gain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined by approximately 179 points to close at 48,892.47, while the S&P 500 fell 0.43% to 6,939.03 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.94% to 23,461.82. The Nasdaq experienced a drop of over 200 points during the session. Although the market showed signs of declining investor sentiment, the CNN Fear & Greed Index remained in the 'Greed' zone at 57.9, down from 60.5 the previous day. Most S&P 500 sectors ended lower, with materials, technology, and financials recording the largest losses; however, consumer staples and energy sectors rose despite the broader market trend. Key economic data showed the U.S. Producer Price Index (PPI) rose 0.5% month-over-month in December—the largest increase in three months—surpassing both the prior month's 0.2% rise and the market forecast of 0.2%. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) reported stronger-than-expected financial results for Q1 of fiscal year 2026 after the market close on Thursday, and Verizon Communications (NYSE:VZ) delivered better-than-forecast fourth-quarter results and raised its adjusted EPS guidance for fiscal year 2026 above expectations. Investors are awaiting earnings reports from Walt Disney (NYSE:DIS), Tyson Foods (NYSE:TSN), and NXP Semiconductors (NASDAQ:NXPI) on the same day. The CNN Fear & Greed Index, ranging from 0 (maximum fear) to 100 (maximum greed), is calculated using seven equally weighted indicators to assess market sentiment.
Original language: ko
Publish date: February 02, 2026 08:15 AM
Source:[Benzinga Korea](https://www.benzinga.com/content/50290576/s-p-500-3-1)

**Apple (AAPL) Reports Record Revenue, Exceeds Market Expectations**
Apple (AAPL) reported record first-quarter fiscal year 2026 revenue of $143.8 billion, a 16% year-over-year increase, surpassing the market consensus of $138.5 billion. Earnings per share reached $2.84, exceeding the expected $2.68. The company's gross margin was 48.2%, outperforming its own guidance and reflecting strong operational efficiency. Citi forecasts second-quarter revenue growth between 13% and 16% year-over-year, citing ongoing supply constraints for advanced iPhone process capacity. Service revenue growth is expected to remain consistent, with gross margins projected between 48% and 49%. Operating expenses are estimated at $18.4 billion to $18.7 billion, and the tax rate is anticipated to be around 17.5%. Based on a projected fiscal year 2026 earnings per share of $8.97 and a price-to-earnings ratio of 30x, Citi has raised Apple's target price to $269.01 and maintained its 'outperform' rating.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 02, 2026 08:10 AM
Source:[GuruFocus](https://www.gurufocus.com/news/8571900/apple-aapl-reports-record-revenue-exceeds-market-expectations)

**S&P 500 Declines For Third Consecutive Session But Records Gain In January: Investor Sentiment Declines, Fear Index Remains In 'Greed' Zone**
The S&P 500 declined for the third consecutive session on Friday, February 2, 2026, closing down 0.43% to 6,939.03, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.94% to 23,461.82 and the Dow Jones dropped 179 points to 48,892.47. Despite the three-day losing streak, the S&P 500 posted a 1.4% gain for January 2026, the Dow rose 1.7%, and the Nasdaq gained 1%. Strong earnings reports from Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) and Verizon Communications Inc. (NYSE:VZ) after the market close on Thursday contributed to positive sentiment, with Apple reporting better-than-expected Q1 fiscal 2026 results and Verizon delivering strong Q4 results and above-estimate FY26 adjusted EPS guidance. On the economic front, U.S. producer prices rose 0.5% month-over-month in December—the largest increase in three months—exceeding the expected 0.2%. Most S&P 500 sectors ended lower, with materials, information technology, and financials recording the largest losses; however, consumer staples and energy stocks closed higher. The CNN Money Fear and Greed Index fell to 57.9 from 60.5, remaining in the 'Greed' zone (which spans 51–100), indicating that investor sentiment declined but still reflects optimism. The index is based on seven equal-weighted indicators measuring market fear and greed, ranging from 0 (maximum fear) to 100 (maximum greed). Investors are awaiting earnings from Walt Disney Co (NYSE:DIS), Tyson Foods Inc. (NYSE:TSN), and NXP Semiconductors NV (NASDAQ:NXPI).
Original language: en
Publish date: February 02, 2026 06:05 AM
Source:[Benzinga News](https://www.benzinga.com/markets/equities/26/02/50290428/sp-500-declines-for-third-consecutive-session-but-records-gain-in-january-investor-sentiment-declines-fear-index-remains-in-greed-zone)

**Weekend News Roundup - Newsquawk Asia-Pac Market Open**
On February 1, 2026, US stocks ended lower despite mixed signals, with Materials and Tech sectors leading losses amid a sharp correction in precious metals. Apple (AAPL) closed flat despite beating earnings expectations, as concerns over weak services revenue and memory shortages weighed on sentiment; defensive sectors like Consumer Staples and Healthcare showed resilience. Chinese PMIs fell into contraction territory, with Manufacturing PMI at 49.3 (vs. expected 50.1), Non-Manufacturing at 49.4 (vs. expected 50.3), and Composite at 49.8 (vs. previous 50.7). US President Trump warned of a 'very substantial response' if Canada signs a trade deal with China, while also stating that Fed Chair nominee Kevin Warsh may cut rates without White House pressure, though Warsh has not committed to rate cuts. Fed officials Musalem (2028 voter) emphasized policy is neutral and further cuts are not advisable, while Bowman (voter) supported a pause due to elevated inflation and persistent labor market risks, projecting three cuts by 2026. The US Senate passed a $1.2 trillion government funding deal 71-29, with the House expected to vote soon after a brief shutdown. Trump appointed Brett Matusmoto to head the BLS, and Commerce Secretary Lutnick was linked to a planned visit to Epstein’s island per DOJ files. NVIDIA reportedly halted a $100 billion investment in OpenAI due to internal disagreements. OPEC+ members agreed to maintain the pause in oil output hikes in March. In commodities, CME raised gold and silver margins following a historic Comex slump—gold margins rose from 6% to 8% (non-heightened) and 6.6% to 8.8% (heightened), silver from 11% to 15% (non-heightened) and 12.1% to 16.5% (heightened). Geopolitically, Iran’s Supreme Leader Khamenei warned US war would escalate regionally, while Iranian military chief Hatami threatened Israel. US-Iran talks may occur in Turkey. The US approved $16 billion in arms sales to Israel and Saudi Arabia. Ukraine’s Zelensky announced trilateral peace talks with the US and Russia in Abu Dhabi on February 4–5. US envoy Witkoff held constructive talks with Russia’s Dmitriev. Russia claimed control of two villages in Kharkiv and Donetsk, and Medvedev claimed victory is near while praising Trump as an effective peace-seeking leader. Trump also claimed progress on deals with Cuba and Greenland. In Asia-Pacific, Chinese President Xi called for the renminbi to become a global reserve currency. Japan’s PM Takaichi said yen depreciation helped exporters and foreign exchange returns but clarified she meant building resilience, not advocating for a weak currency. India increased infrastructure spending by 9% to INR 12.2 trillion, proposed tax holidays until 2047 for foreign cloud data center investors, targeted debt-to-GDP reduction to 50% by 2030–2031, and raised Securities Transaction Tax on futures and options.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 01, 2026 10:44 PM
Source:[Zero Hedge](https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/weekend-news-roundup-newsquawk-asia-pac-market-open-45)

**MASTERINVEST Kapitalanlage GmbH Has $41.94 Million Stock Holdings in Apple Inc. $AAPL**
MASTERINVEST Kapitalanlage GmbH held $41.94 million worth of Apple Inc. (NASDAQ: AAPL) stock at the end of the third quarter of 2025, representing its third-largest holding and accounting for approximately 4.1% of the firm's portfolio. The institutional investor reduced its stake by 3.6% during the quarter, selling 6,185 shares and leaving it with 164,708 shares. Other institutional investors also adjusted their positions: Financial Futures Ltd Liability Co. increased its stake by 13.2%, Monarch Capital Management Inc. by 4.6%, American National Bank & Trust by 2.4%, Riverwater Partners LLC by 17.9%, and Highland Capital Management LLC by 2.2%. Collectively, institutional investors and hedge funds own 67.73% of Apple's shares. Apple reported strong financial results on January 29, 2026, with $2.84 EPS (beating the $2.67 estimate) and $143.76 billion in revenue (exceeding the $138.25 billion consensus), driven by record iPhone sales and strong guidance. Analysts issued mixed sentiment: bullish on revenue and AI partnerships (e.g., Google Gemini), but cautious on AI execution clarity, rising memory costs, TSMC supply constraints, and AI talent departures. Apple's stock closed at $259.48 on February 1, 2026, with a market cap of $3.81 trillion, a P/E ratio of 32.80, and a dividend yield of 0.4% (annualized $1.04). The company declared a quarterly dividend of $0.26 per share, payable on February 12, 2026, to shareholders of record on February 9. Insider Chris Kondo sold 3,752 shares on November 7, 2025, reducing his ownership by 19.90%. Wall Street analysts assigned 1 Strong Buy, 22 Buy, 11 Hold, and 1 Sell rating, resulting in a consensus 'Moderate Buy' and a target price of $289.23. Apple Inc. was founded in 1976 in Cupertino, California, and designs, develops, and sells consumer electronics, software, and services, including the iPhone, iPad, Mac, Apple Watch, AirPods, and HomePod.

Source:[Defense World](https://www.defenseworld.net/2026/02/01/masterinvest-kapitalanlage-gmbh-has-41-94-million-stock-holdings-in-apple-inc-aapl.html)

**U.S. Stock Market Declines Amid Uncertainty Over Next Fed Chair and Rate Cut Expectations**
The U.S. stock market declined on January 30, 2026, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 48,892.47, down 179.09 points, and the Nasdaq Composite ending at 23,461.82, down 223.30 points. The S&P 500 also fell to 6,939.03, down 29.98 points. The downturn followed a stronger-than-expected December 2025 Producer Price Index (PPI) and the announcement by former President Donald Trump that Kevin Warsh, a known hawkish figure, would become the next Federal Reserve Chair. This shift increased uncertainty around future interest rate cuts, prompting investors to take profits. Sector-wise, telecommunications services rose while semiconductors and related manufacturing declined. SanDisk (SNDK) surged on strong second-quarter results and robust demand for AI data center memory chips. Apple (AAPL) rose despite concerns over memory price increases and supply constraints. Gold miner Newmont (NEM) fell sharply as the dollar strengthened and gold prices dropped, with silver prices plunging over 30% at one point. Silver producers such as Hudbay Minerals (HL), Coeur Mining (CDE), and Pan American Silver (PAAS) saw significant sell-offs. Footwear company Deckers Outdoor (DECK) surged after reporting better-than-expected earnings and raising its full-year outlook, driven by strong performance in brands like UGG and HOKA. Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman indicated in a CNBC interview that Kevin Warsh is likely to succeed her as Fed Chair upon her term's expiration on March 31, 2026.

**Apple Just Delivered Great News For This Market-Crushing AI Stock**
Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) reported strong fiscal first-quarter earnings, with revenue rising 16% year-over-year to $143.8 billion and iPhone sales increasing 23% to $85.3 billion, surpassing analyst estimates. CEO Tim Cook acknowledged that rising memory prices, driven by high demand for AI applications, would negatively impact gross margins in Q2 and beyond, stating, 'Beyond Q2, we do continue to see market pricing for memory increasing significantly.' Micron (NASDAQ: MU), a key U.S.-based memory chip supplier for Apple—having sourced 20 billion chips from the U.S. in 2025—is positioned to benefit significantly from this trend. The company is a major producer of high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips used in AI data centers, and its stock has surged amid a memory chip supply crunch. Micron's fiscal second-quarter earnings per share guidance nearly doubled analyst expectations, and the stock trades at a forward price-to-earnings ratio of 13 based on fiscal 2026 estimates. Analysts project revenue could double in 2026, with AI-driven demand expected to sustain growth through at least 2028, making Micron a strong buy despite the cyclical nature of the memory sector.

**Should You Buy Apple Stock Now for Record iPhone Sales?**
Apple (AAPL) stock is slightly declining on January 30, 2026, due to rising memory costs, despite record revenue driven by unprecedented iPhone demand in fiscal Q1. However, JPMorgan senior analyst Samik Chatterjee maintains a 'Buy' rating, citing that AAPL is trading at a forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of approximately 31x—lower than its historical levels during prior super cycles. Chatterjee argues that Apple’s long-term supplier contracts mitigate margin pressure from higher memory costs and anticipates strong future growth driven by a multi-year artificial intelligence (AI) upgrade cycle. He projects a price target of $315, implying nearly 24% upside from current levels. Additional catalysts include Apple’s partnership with Google to integrate Gemini into its ecosystem, a planned Siri revamp, and speculation about a foldable iPhone launch by late 2026, which could increase average selling prices (ASPs) and boost share prices in 2026. Options traders also show confidence, with the upper strike price for contracts expiring mid-April set at $275. The broader Wall Street consensus remains 'Moderate Buy' with a mean price target of $289, indicating about 14% potential upside.

**Apple (AAPL) Stock: Breaks Losing Run as Analysts Turn More Bullish Before Results**

The upcoming earnings report will center on three key signals: iPhone demand trajectory, services revenue growth, and tangible advancements in AI integration. **Apple is an Analyst Favorite, But AAPL Stock Has Been Flat - Shorting Puts Is the Best Play**
Apple Inc. (AAPL) stock has traded in a narrow range between $268.47 (Nov. 7 low) and $286.19 (Dec. 2 closing peak) as of Dec. 30, 2025, with a current price of $272.93. Despite analysts' average price target of $287.74—5.4% above the current price, and individual targets ranging from $285.20 to $327—AAPL has shown minimal price movement. The author argues that shorting out-of-the-money (OTM) put options has been the best strategy over the past month, citing a significant drop in premium values: from $2.27 and $3.40 to $0.13 and $0.61, respectively, for the $265.00 and $270.00 strike puts expiring Jan. 2, 2026. The author recommends rolling the trade into a new expiration, such as the Jan. 30, 2026, $260.00 put, which offers a 1.04% monthly yield ($2.70 premium on a $260 strike). This strategy allows investors to collect income while waiting for a potential upside, with the obligation to buy AAPL at a price nearly 5% below the current market value. The author's own price target is $325, 19% above the current price, based on strong free cash flow and FCF margins.

**Apple (AAPL): Evaluating Valuation After Recent Investor Interest and Share Price Momentum**
Apple (AAPL) shares rose 6.8% over the past month, closing at $262.24 on October 21, 2025, driven by recent momentum following headline announcements and consistent profit growth. The company's 1-year total shareholder return stands at 11.7%, reflecting durable long-term performance. However, investor debate persists over valuation: the most popular narrative labels Apple as 'overvalued,' estimating a fair value of $177.34, based on a P/E ratio exceeding 28x—well above the broader market average of ~20x. This high multiple is seen as unsustainable given Apple's mature product lines and market saturation. A separate SWS DCF model estimates a fair value of $219.41, still below the current share price, suggesting even fundamental cash flow analysis reflects a premium valuation. Despite this, strong service growth or unexpected innovation could challenge the overvaluation thesis and reignite investor momentum.

**Apple Shares (AAPL) Close To Reaching A Record High - FinanceFeeds**
On 10 September, Apple Inc. (AAPL) shares fell about 1.5% after the company unveiled the iPhone 17, as analysts questioned the model’s breakthrough appeal. Two weeks later, media reports highlighted strong demand, noting that orders for the new devices exceed those of last year’s iPhone 16 series, Apple has requested suppliers to increase production, and the base model with a 120Hz display and A19 chip is attracting high demand. Positive reports of long queues at Apple Stores worldwide and extended delivery times—Bank of America estimates an average of 18 days versus 10 days for the previous model—have bolstered bullish sentiment. AAPL shares are rising this week while broader market indices decline. Technical analysis shows the 2025 price action forming a broad ascending channel. Until early August, the price consolidated below the channel’s median; since then, buyers have gained strength, creating a steep growth channel with the median acting as support. The price rose from $240 to $250, with broad bullish candlesticks, close-to-high closing prices, and a clear bullish gap, indicating a buyers’ imbalance and a support zone per the Fair Value Gap pattern. From a bearish view, the RSI is overbought and some shareholders may realize profits, but the upward trend could continue if strong demand for the iPhone 17, Apple Watch Series 11, and AirPods Pro 3 with AI‑driven features drives record quarterly revenue, especially during the holiday season. Bulls may target the upper boundary of the blue channel as a price objective. --- Deep Research Analysis ---
**Latest Analyst Commentary on Apple Post-Q1 2026 Earnings & February 2026 Outlook**  

### Key Earnings Takeaways  
Apple delivered a record Q1 FY2026 performance, with revenue hitting $143.8B (+16% YoY) and EPS of $2.84 (+19% YoY), beating consensus estimates [1][4][8][9]. The iPhone 17 drove 23% sales growth ($85.3B), especially in China (+38%), while services reached $30B (+14% YoY) [4][5][8][9]. Despite this, shares fell 0.58% on February 2 amid broader market declines and supply chain concerns [2][3].  

### February 2026 Product Demand Trends & Stock Impact  
1. **iPhone Supply Squeeze**:  
   - Unprecedented demand faces memory chip shortages, with CEO Tim Cook noting "very low inventory" [5].  
   - Analysts expect 13-16% Q2 revenue growth only if supply stabilizes [1][5][10]. Weakness here could pressure near-term stock performance.  

2. **Services as Margin Hedge**:  
   - With 2.5B active devices, services growth (+14% projected) may offset hardware margin pressures from component inflation [4][5][9]. This diversification is viewed positively by analysts [6][7].  

3. **Valuation Headwinds**:  
   - Trading at 30-32x forward P/E, the stock is seen as "appropriately priced" with limited upside without new catalysts (e.g., AI breakthroughs or foldable iPhone) [4][7].  

4. **Key Catalysts to Watch**:  
   - **AI Integration**: Post-Google partnership progress could justify premium valuation if execution improves [7].  
   - **Component Cost Controls**: Rising memory chip expenses threaten margins; resolution would boost sentiment [5][7].  

### Analyst Consensus  
- **Rating**: "Moderate Buy" (1 Strong Buy, 22 Buy, 11 Hold, 1 Sell) [6][7].  
- **Price Target**: Average $289.23 (Citi at $269) [1][7].  
- **Risks Highlighted**:  
  - Supply chain instability (especially memory chips) [5][7]  
  - AI strategy ambiguity after talent departures [6][7]  
  - China geopolitical tensions [5][8]  

### Outlook  
Analysts project **neutral-to-positive near-term stock performance** contingent on:  
- Successful navigation of supply constraints for February/March iPhone demand.  
- Services growth absorbing hardware margin pressures.  
- Clearer AI roadmaps to sustain premium valuation.  
Failure on these fronts may cap upside despite strong fundamentals.
